speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
text_entry: SCENE I. Venice. A street.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
text_entry: Enter ANTONIO, SALARINO, and SALANIO

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: In sooth, I know not why I am so sad:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: It wearies me; you say it wearies you;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: But how I caught it, found it, or came by it,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: What stuff 'tis made of, whereof it is born,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I am to learn;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And such a want-wit sadness makes of me,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: That I have much ado to know myself.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Your mind is tossing on the ocean;

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: There, where your argosies with portly sail,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Like signiors and rich burghers on the flood,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Or, as it were, the pageants of the sea,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Do overpeer the petty traffickers,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: That curtsy to them, do them reverence,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: As they fly by them with their woven wings.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Believe me, sir, had I such venture forth,

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: The better part of my affections would

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Be with my hopes abroad. I should be still

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Plucking the grass, to know where sits the wind,

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Peering in maps for ports and piers and roads;

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: And every object that might make me fear

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Misfortune to my ventures, out of doubt

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Would make me sad.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: My wind cooling my broth

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Would blow me to an ague, when I thought

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: What harm a wind too great at sea might do.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: I should not see the sandy hour-glass run,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: But I should think of shallows and of flats,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And see my wealthy Andrew dock'd in sand,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Vailing her high-top lower than her ribs

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: To kiss her burial. Should I go to church

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And see the holy edifice of stone,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And not bethink me straight of dangerous rocks,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Which touching but my gentle vessel's side,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Would scatter all her spices on the stream,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Enrobe the roaring waters with my silks,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And, in a word, but even now worth this,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And now worth nothing? Shall I have the thought

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: To think on this, and shall I lack the thought

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: That such a thing bechanced would make me sad?

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: But tell not me; I know, Antonio

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Is sad to think upon his merchandise.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Believe me, no: I thank my fortune for it,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: My ventures are not in one bottom trusted,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Nor to one place; nor is my whole estate

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Upon the fortune of this present year:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Why, then you are in love.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Fie, fie!

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Not in love neither? Then let us say you are sad,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Because you are not merry: and 'twere as easy

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: For you to laugh and leap and say you are merry,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Because you are not sad. Now, by two-headed Janus,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Nature hath framed strange fellows in her time:

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Some that will evermore peep through their eyes

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And laugh like parrots at a bag-piper,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And other of such vinegar aspect

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: That they'll not show their teeth in way of smile,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Enter BASSANIO, LORENZO, and GRATIANO

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Here comes Bassanio, your most noble kinsman,

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Gratiano and Lorenzo. Fare ye well:

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: We leave you now with better company.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: I would have stay'd till I had made you merry,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: If worthier friends had not prevented me.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Your worth is very dear in my regard.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I take it, your own business calls on you

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And you embrace the occasion to depart.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Good morrow, my good lords.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Good signiors both, when shall we laugh? say, when?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: You grow exceeding strange: must it be so?

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: We'll make our leisures to attend on yours.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Exeunt Salarino and Salanio

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: My Lord Bassanio, since you have found Antonio,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: We two will leave you: but at dinner-time,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I pray you, have in mind where we must meet.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I will not fail you.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: You look not well, Signior Antonio;

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: You have too much respect upon the world:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: They lose it that do buy it with much care:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Believe me, you are marvellously changed.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I hold the world but as the world, Gratiano;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: A stage where every man must play a part,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And mine a sad one.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Let me play the fool:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: With mirth and laughter let old wrinkles come,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: And let my liver rather heat with wine

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Than my heart cool with mortifying groans.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Why should a man, whose blood is warm within,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Sit like his grandsire cut in alabaster?

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Sleep when he wakes and creep into the jaundice

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: By being peevish? I tell thee what, Antonio--

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: I love thee, and it is my love that speaks--

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: There are a sort of men whose visages

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Do cream and mantle like a standing pond,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: And do a wilful stillness entertain,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: With purpose to be dress'd in an opinion

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Of wisdom, gravity, profound conceit,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: As who should say 'I am Sir Oracle,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: And when I ope my lips let no dog bark!'

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: O my Antonio, I do know of these

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: That therefore only are reputed wise

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: For saying nothing; when, I am very sure,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: If they should speak, would almost damn those ears,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Which, hearing them, would call their brothers fools.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: I'll tell thee more of this another time:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: But fish not, with this melancholy bait,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: For this fool gudgeon, this opinion.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Come, good Lorenzo. Fare ye well awhile:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: I'll end my exhortation after dinner.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Well, we will leave you then till dinner-time:

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I must be one of these same dumb wise men,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: For Gratiano never lets me speak.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Well, keep me company but two years moe,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Thou shalt not know the sound of thine own tongue.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Farewell: I'll grow a talker for this gear.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Thanks, i' faith, for silence is only commendable

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: In a neat's tongue dried and a maid not vendible.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Exeunt GRATIANO and LORENZO

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Is that any thing now?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing, more

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: than any man in all Venice. His reasons are as two

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: grains of wheat hid in two bushels of chaff: you

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: shall seek all day ere you find them, and when you

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: have them, they are not worth the search.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Well, tell me now what lady is the same

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To whom you swore a secret pilgrimage,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: That you to-day promised to tell me of?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: 'Tis not unknown to you, Antonio,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: How much I have disabled mine estate,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: By something showing a more swelling port

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Than my faint means would grant continuance:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Nor do I now make moan to be abridged

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: From such a noble rate; but my chief care

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Is to come fairly off from the great debts

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Wherein my time something too prodigal

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Hath left me gaged. To you, Antonio,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I owe the most, in money and in love,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And from your love I have a warranty

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To unburden all my plots and purposes

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: How to get clear of all the debts I owe.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I pray you, good Bassanio, let me know it;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And if it stand, as you yourself still do,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Within the eye of honour, be assured,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: My purse, my person, my extremest means,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Lie all unlock'd to your occasions.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: In my school-days, when I had lost one shaft,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I shot his fellow of the self-same flight

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The self-same way with more advised watch,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To find the other forth, and by adventuring both

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I oft found both: I urge this childhood proof,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Because what follows is pure innocence.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I owe you much, and, like a wilful youth,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: That which I owe is lost; but if you please

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To shoot another arrow that self way

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Which you did shoot the first, I do not doubt,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: As I will watch the aim, or to find both

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Or bring your latter hazard back again

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And thankfully rest debtor for the first.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: You know me well, and herein spend but time

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To wind about my love with circumstance;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And out of doubt you do me now more wrong

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: In making question of my uttermost

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Than if you had made waste of all I have:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Then do but say to me what I should do

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: That in your knowledge may by me be done,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And I am prest unto it: therefore, speak.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: In Belmont is a lady richly left;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And she is fair, and, fairer than that word,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Of wondrous virtues: sometimes from her eyes

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I did receive fair speechless messages:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Her name is Portia, nothing undervalued

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To Cato's daughter, Brutus' Portia:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Nor is the wide world ignorant of her worth,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: For the four winds blow in from every coast

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Renowned suitors, and her sunny locks

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Hang on her temples like a golden fleece;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Which makes her seat of Belmont Colchos' strand,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And many Jasons come in quest of her.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: O my Antonio, had I but the means

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To hold a rival place with one of them,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I have a mind presages me such thrift,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: That I should questionless be fortunate!

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Thou know'st that all my fortunes are at sea;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Neither have I money nor commodity

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To raise a present sum: therefore go forth;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Try what my credit can in Venice do:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: That shall be rack'd, even to the uttermost,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To furnish thee to Belmont, to fair Portia.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Go, presently inquire, and so will I,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Where money is, and I no question make

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To have it of my trust or for my sake.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: SCENE II: Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Enter PORTIA and NERISSA

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: By my troth, Nerissa, my little body is aweary of

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: this great world.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: You would be, sweet madam, if your miseries were in

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: the same abundance as your good fortunes are: and

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: yet, for aught I see, they are as sick that surfeit

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: with too much as they that starve with nothing. It

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: is no mean happiness therefore, to be seated in the

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: mean: superfluity comes sooner by white hairs, but

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: competency lives longer.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Good sentences and well pronounced.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: They would be better, if well followed.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If to do were as easy as to know what were good to

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: do, chapels had been churches and poor men's

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: cottages princes' palaces. It is a good divine that

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: follows his own instructions: I can easier teach

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: twenty what were good to be done, than be one of the

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: twenty to follow mine own teaching. The brain may

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: devise laws for the blood, but a hot temper leaps

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: o'er a cold decree: such a hare is madness the

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: youth, to skip o'er the meshes of good counsel the

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: cripple. But this reasoning is not in the fashion to

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: choose me a husband. O me, the word 'choose!' I may

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: neither choose whom I would nor refuse whom I

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: dislike; so is the will of a living daughter curbed

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: by the will of a dead father. Is it not hard,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Nerissa, that I cannot choose one nor refuse none?

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Your father was ever virtuous; and holy men at their

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: death have good inspirations: therefore the lottery,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: that he hath devised in these three chests of gold,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: silver and lead, whereof who chooses his meaning

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: chooses you, will, no doubt, never be chosen by any

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: rightly but one who shall rightly love. But what

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: warmth is there in your affection towards any of

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: these princely suitors that are already come?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I pray thee, over-name them; and as thou namest

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: them, I will describe them; and, according to my

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: description, level at my affection.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: First, there is the Neapolitan prince.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Ay, that's a colt indeed, for he doth nothing but

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: talk of his horse; and he makes it a great

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: appropriation to his own good parts, that he can

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: shoe him himself. I am much afeard my lady his

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: mother played false with a smith.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Then there is the County Palatine.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: He doth nothing but frown, as who should say 'If you

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: will not have me, choose:' he hears merry tales and

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: smiles not: I fear he will prove the weeping

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: philosopher when he grows old, being so full of

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: unmannerly sadness in his youth. I had rather be

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: married to a death's-head with a bone in his mouth

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: than to either of these. God defend me from these

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: two!

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: How say you by the French lord, Monsieur Le Bon?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: God made him, and therefore let him pass for a man.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: In truth, I know it is a sin to be a mocker: but,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: he! why, he hath a horse better than the

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Neapolitan's, a better bad habit of frowning than

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: the Count Palatine; he is every man in no man; if a

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: throstle sing, he falls straight a capering: he will

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: fence with his own shadow: if I should marry him, I

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: should marry twenty husbands. If he would despise me

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I would forgive him, for if he love me to madness, I

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: shall never requite him.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: What say you, then, to Falconbridge, the young baron

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: of England?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You know I say nothing to him, for he understands

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: not me, nor I him: he hath neither Latin, French,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: nor Italian, and you will come into the court and

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: swear that I have a poor pennyworth in the English.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: He is a proper man's picture, but, alas, who can

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: converse with a dumb-show? How oddly he is suited!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I think he bought his doublet in Italy, his round

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: hose in France, his bonnet in Germany and his

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: behavior every where.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: What think you of the Scottish lord, his neighbour?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That he hath a neighbourly charity in him, for he

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: borrowed a box of the ear of the Englishman and

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: swore he would pay him again when he was able: I

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: think the Frenchman became his surety and sealed

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: under for another.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: How like you the young German, the Duke of Saxony's nephew?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Very vilely in the morning, when he is sober, and

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: most vilely in the afternoon, when he is drunk: when

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: he is best, he is a little worse than a man, and

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: when he is worst, he is little better than a beast:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: and the worst fall that ever fell, I hope I shall

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: make shift to go without him.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: If he should offer to choose, and choose the right

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: casket, you should refuse to perform your father's

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: will, if you should refuse to accept him.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Therefore, for fear of the worst, I pray thee, set a

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: deep glass of rhenish wine on the contrary casket,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: for if the devil be within and that temptation

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: without, I know he will choose it. I will do any

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: thing, Nerissa, ere I'll be married to a sponge.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: You need not fear, lady, the having any of these

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: lords: they have acquainted me with their

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: determinations; which is, indeed, to return to their

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: home and to trouble you with no more suit, unless

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: you may be won by some other sort than your father's

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: imposition depending on the caskets.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If I live to be as old as Sibylla, I will die as

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: chaste as Diana, unless I be obtained by the manner

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: of my father's will. I am glad this parcel of wooers

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: are so reasonable, for there is not one among them

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: but I dote on his very absence, and I pray God grant

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: them a fair departure.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Do you not remember, lady, in your father's time, a

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Venetian, a scholar and a soldier, that came hither

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: in company of the Marquis of Montferrat?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Yes, yes, it was Bassanio; as I think, he was so called.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: True, madam: he, of all the men that ever my foolish

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: eyes looked upon, was the best deserving a fair lady.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I remember him well, and I remember him worthy of

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: thy praise.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Enter a Serving-man

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: How now! what news?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: The four strangers seek for you, madam, to take

speaker: Servant
text_entry: their leave: and there is a forerunner come from a

speaker: Servant
text_entry: fifth, the Prince of Morocco, who brings word the

speaker: Servant
text_entry: prince his master will be here to-night.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If I could bid the fifth welcome with so good a

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: heart as I can bid the other four farewell, I should

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: be glad of his approach: if he have the condition

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: of a saint and the complexion of a devil, I had

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: rather he should shrive me than wive me. Come,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Nerissa. Sirrah, go before.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Whiles we shut the gates

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: upon one wooer, another knocks at the door.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: SCENE III. Venice. A public place.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Enter BASSANIO and SHYLOCK

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Three thousand ducats; well.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Ay, sir, for three months.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: For three months; well.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: For the which, as I told you, Antonio shall be bound.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Antonio shall become bound; well.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: May you stead me? will you pleasure me? shall I

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: know your answer?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Three thousand ducats for three months and Antonio bound.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Your answer to that.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Antonio is a good man.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Have you heard any imputation to the contrary?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Oh, no, no, no, no: my meaning in saying he is a

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: good man is to have you understand me that he is

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: sufficient. Yet his means are in supposition: he

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: hath an argosy bound to Tripolis, another to the

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Indies; I understand moreover, upon the Rialto, he

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: hath a third at Mexico, a fourth for England, and

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: other ventures he hath, squandered abroad. But ships

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: are but boards, sailors but men: there be land-rats

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: and water-rats, water-thieves and land-thieves, I

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: mean pirates, and then there is the peril of waters,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: winds and rocks. The man is, notwithstanding,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: sufficient. Three thousand ducats; I think I may

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: take his bond.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Be assured you may.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I will be assured I may; and, that I may be assured,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I will bethink me. May I speak with Antonio?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: If it please you to dine with us.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Yes, to smell pork; to eat of the habitation which

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: your prophet the Nazarite conjured the devil into. I

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: will buy with you, sell with you, talk with you,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: walk with you, and so following, but I will not eat

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: with you, drink with you, nor pray with you. What

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: news on the Rialto? Who is he comes here?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Enter ANTONIO

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: This is Signior Antonio.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: [Aside]  How like a fawning publican he looks!

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I hate him for he is a Christian,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: But more for that in low simplicity

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: He lends out money gratis and brings down

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: The rate of usance here with us in Venice.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: If I can catch him once upon the hip,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I will feed fat the ancient grudge I bear him.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: He hates our sacred nation, and he rails,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Even there where merchants most do congregate,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: On me, my bargains and my well-won thrift,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Which he calls interest. Cursed be my tribe,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: If I forgive him!

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Shylock, do you hear?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I am debating of my present store,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: And, by the near guess of my memory,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I cannot instantly raise up the gross

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Of full three thousand ducats. What of that?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Tubal, a wealthy Hebrew of my tribe,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Will furnish me. But soft! how many months

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Do you desire?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: To ANTONIO

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Rest you fair, good signior;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Your worship was the last man in our mouths.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Shylock, although I neither lend nor borrow

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: By taking nor by giving of excess,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Yet, to supply the ripe wants of my friend,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I'll break a custom. Is he yet possess'd

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: How much ye would?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Ay, ay, three thousand ducats.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And for three months.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I had forgot; three months; you told me so.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Well then, your bond; and let me see; but hear you;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Methought you said you neither lend nor borrow

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Upon advantage.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I do never use it.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: When Jacob grazed his uncle Laban's sheep--

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: This Jacob from our holy Abram was,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: As his wise mother wrought in his behalf,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: The third possessor; ay, he was the third--

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And what of him? did he take interest?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: No, not take interest, not, as you would say,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Directly interest: mark what Jacob did.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: When Laban and himself were compromised

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: That all the eanlings which were streak'd and pied

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Should fall as Jacob's hire, the ewes, being rank,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: In the end of autumn turned to the rams,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: And, when the work of generation was

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Between these woolly breeders in the act,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: The skilful shepherd peel'd me certain wands,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: And, in the doing of the deed of kind,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: He stuck them up before the fulsome ewes,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Who then conceiving did in eaning time

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Fall parti-colour'd lambs, and those were Jacob's.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: This was a way to thrive, and he was blest:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: And thrift is blessing, if men steal it not.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: This was a venture, sir, that Jacob served for;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: A thing not in his power to bring to pass,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: But sway'd and fashion'd by the hand of heaven.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Was this inserted to make interest good?

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I cannot tell; I make it breed as fast:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: But note me, signior.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Mark you this, Bassanio,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: The devil can cite Scripture for his purpose.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: An evil soul producing holy witness

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Is like a villain with a smiling cheek,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: A goodly apple rotten at the heart:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: O, what a goodly outside falsehood hath!

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Three thousand ducats; 'tis a good round sum.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Three months from twelve; then, let me see; the rate--

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Well, Shylock, shall we be beholding to you?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Signior Antonio, many a time and oft

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: In the Rialto you have rated me

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: About my moneys and my usances:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Still have I borne it with a patient shrug,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: For sufferance is the badge of all our tribe.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: You call me misbeliever, cut-throat dog,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: And spit upon my Jewish gaberdine,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: And all for use of that which is mine own.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Well then, it now appears you need my help:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Go to, then; you come to me, and you say

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: 'Shylock, we would have moneys:' you say so;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: You, that did void your rheum upon my beard

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: And foot me as you spurn a stranger cur

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Over your threshold: moneys is your suit

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: What should I say to you? Should I not say

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: 'Hath a dog money? is it possible

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: A cur can lend three thousand ducats?' Or

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Shall I bend low and in a bondman's key,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: With bated breath and whispering humbleness, Say this;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: 'Fair sir, you spit on me on Wednesday last;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: You spurn'd me such a day; another time

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: You call'd me dog; and for these courtesies

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I'll lend you thus much moneys'?

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I am as like to call thee so again,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To spit on thee again, to spurn thee too.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: If thou wilt lend this money, lend it not

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: As to thy friends; for when did friendship take

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: A breed for barren metal of his friend?

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: But lend it rather to thine enemy,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Who, if he break, thou mayst with better face

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Exact the penalty.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Why, look you, how you storm!

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I would be friends with you and have your love,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Forget the shames that you have stain'd me with,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Supply your present wants and take no doit

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Of usance for my moneys, and you'll not hear me:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: This is kind I offer.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: This were kindness.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: This kindness will I show.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Go with me to a notary, seal me there

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Your single bond; and, in a merry sport,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: If you repay me not on such a day,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: In such a place, such sum or sums as are

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Express'd in the condition, let the forfeit

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Be nominated for an equal pound

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Of your fair flesh, to be cut off and taken

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: In what part of your body pleaseth me.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Content, i' faith: I'll seal to such a bond

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And say there is much kindness in the Jew.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: You shall not seal to such a bond for me:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I'll rather dwell in my necessity.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Why, fear not, man; I will not forfeit it:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Within these two months, that's a month before

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: This bond expires, I do expect return

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Of thrice three times the value of this bond.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: O father Abram, what these Christians are,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Whose own hard dealings teaches them suspect

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: The thoughts of others! Pray you, tell me this;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: If he should break his day, what should I gain

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: By the exaction of the forfeiture?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: A pound of man's flesh taken from a man

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Is not so estimable, profitable neither,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: As flesh of muttons, beefs, or goats. I say,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: To buy his favour, I extend this friendship:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: If he will take it, so; if not, adieu;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: And, for my love, I pray you wrong me not.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Yes Shylock, I will seal unto this bond.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Then meet me forthwith at the notary's;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Give him direction for this merry bond,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: And I will go and purse the ducats straight,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: See to my house, left in the fearful guard

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Of an unthrifty knave, and presently

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I will be with you.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Hie thee, gentle Jew.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Exit Shylock

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: The Hebrew will turn Christian: he grows kind.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I like not fair terms and a villain's mind.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Come on: in this there can be no dismay;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: My ships come home a month before the day.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ANTONIO

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: SCENE I. Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Flourish of cornets. Enter the PRINCE OF MOROCCO  and his train; PORTIA, NERISSA, and others attending

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Mislike me not for my complexion,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: The shadow'd livery of the burnish'd sun,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: To whom I am a neighbour and near bred.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Bring me the fairest creature northward born,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Where Phoebus' fire scarce thaws the icicles,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: And let us make incision for your love,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: To prove whose blood is reddest, his or mine.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: I tell thee, lady, this aspect of mine

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Hath fear'd the valiant: by my love I swear

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: The best-regarded virgins of our clime

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Have loved it too: I would not change this hue,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Except to steal your thoughts, my gentle queen.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: In terms of choice I am not solely led

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: By nice direction of a maiden's eyes;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Besides, the lottery of my destiny

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Bars me the right of voluntary choosing:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But if my father had not scanted me

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And hedged me by his wit, to yield myself

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: His wife who wins me by that means I told you,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Yourself, renowned prince, then stood as fair

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: As any comer I have look'd on yet

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: For my affection.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Even for that I thank you:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Therefore, I pray you, lead me to the caskets

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: To try my fortune. By this scimitar

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: That won three fields of Sultan Solyman,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: I would outstare the sternest eyes that look,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Outbrave the heart most daring on the earth,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Yea, mock the lion when he roars for prey,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: To win thee, lady. But, alas the while!

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: If Hercules and Lichas play at dice

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Which is the better man, the greater throw

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: May turn by fortune from the weaker hand:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: So is Alcides beaten by his page;

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: And so may I, blind fortune leading me,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Miss that which one unworthier may attain,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: And die with grieving.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You must take your chance,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And either not attempt to choose at all

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Or swear before you choose, if you choose wrong

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Never to speak to lady afterward

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: In way of marriage: therefore be advised.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Nor will not. Come, bring me unto my chance.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: First, forward to the temple: after dinner

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Your hazard shall be made.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Good fortune then!

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: To make me blest or cursed'st among men.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Cornets, and exeunt

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: fiend; 'for the heavens, rouse up a brave mind,'

text_entry: man's son,' or rather an honest woman's son; for,

text_entry: indeed, my father did something smack, something

text_entry: grow to, he had a kind of taste; well, my conscience

text_entry: says 'Launcelot, budge not.' 'Budge,' says the

speaker: LAUNCELOT

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: 'Conscience,' say I, 'you counsel well;' ' Fiend,'

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: say I, 'you counsel well:' to be ruled by my

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: conscience, I should stay with the Jew my master,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: who, God bless the mark, is a kind of devil; and, to

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: run away from the Jew, I should be ruled by the

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: fiend, who, saving your reverence, is the devil

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: himself. Certainly the Jew is the very devil

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: incarnal; and, in my conscience, my conscience is

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: but a kind of hard conscience, to offer to counsel

text_entry: me to stay with the Jew. The fiend gives the more

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: friendly counsel: I will run, fiend; my heels are

speaker: LAUNCELOT

text_entry: Master young man, you, I pray you, which is the way

text_entry: to master Jew's?

speaker: LAUNCELOT

text_entry: knows me not: I will try confusions with him.

text_entry: Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way

text_entry: to master Jew's?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but,

text_entry: at the next turning of all, on your left; marry, at

text_entry: of young Master Launcelot?

text_entry: though I say it, is an honest exceeding poor man

text_entry: But I pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, I beseech you,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: talk you of young Master Launcelot?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
