text_entry: give me your blessing: I am Launcelot, your boy

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: that was, your son that is, your child that shall

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: be.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: I cannot think you are my son.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: I know not what I shall think of that: but I am

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Launcelot, the Jew's man, and I am sure Margery your

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: wife is my mother.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Her name is Margery, indeed: I'll be sworn, if thou

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: be Launcelot, thou art mine own flesh and blood.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Lord worshipped might he be! what a beard hast thou

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: got! thou hast got more hair on thy chin than

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Dobbin my fill-horse has on his tail.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: It should seem, then, that Dobbin's tail grows

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: backward: I am sure he had more hair of his tail

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: than I have of my face when I last saw him.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Lord, how art thou changed! How dost thou and thy

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: master agree? I have brought him a present. How

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: 'gree you now?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Well, well: but, for mine own part, as I have set

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: up my rest to run away, so I will not rest till I

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: have run some ground. My master's a very Jew: give

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: him a present! give him a halter: I am famished in

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: his service; you may tell every finger I have with

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: my ribs. Father, I am glad you are come: give me

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: your present to one Master Bassanio, who, indeed,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: gives rare new liveries: if I serve not him, I

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: will run as far as God has any ground. O rare

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: fortune! here comes the man: to him, father; for I

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: am a Jew, if I serve the Jew any longer.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Enter BASSANIO, with LEONARDO and other followers

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: You may do so; but let it be so hasted that supper

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: be ready at the farthest by five of the clock. See

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: these letters delivered; put the liveries to making,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: and desire Gratiano to come anon to my lodging.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Exit a Servant

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: To him, father.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: God bless your worship!

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Gramercy! wouldst thou aught with me?

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Here's my son, sir, a poor boy,--

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jew's man; that

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: would, sir, as my father shall specify--

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: He hath a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve--

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Indeed, the short and the long is, I serve the Jew,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: and have a desire, as my father shall specify--

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: His master and he, saving your worship's reverence,

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: are scarce cater-cousins--

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: To be brief, the very truth is that the Jew, having

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: done me wrong, doth cause me, as my father, being, I

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: hope, an old man, shall frutify unto you--

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: I have here a dish of doves that I would bestow upon

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: your worship, and my suit is--

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: In very brief, the suit is impertinent to myself, as

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: your worship shall know by this honest old man; and,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: though I say it, though old man, yet poor man, my father.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: One speak for both. What would you?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Serve you, sir.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: That is the very defect of the matter, sir.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I know thee well; thou hast obtain'd thy suit:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Shylock thy master spoke with me this day,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And hath preferr'd thee, if it be preferment

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To leave a rich Jew's service, to become

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The follower of so poor a gentleman.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: The old proverb is very well parted between my

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: master Shylock and you, sir: you have the grace of

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: God, sir, and he hath enough.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Thou speak'st it well. Go, father, with thy son.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Take leave of thy old master and inquire

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: My lodging out. Give him a livery

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: More guarded than his fellows': see it done.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Father, in. I cannot get a service, no; I have

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: ne'er a tongue in my head. Well, if any man in

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Italy have a fairer table which doth offer to swear

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: upon a book, I shall have good fortune. Go to,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: here's a simple line of life: here's a small trifle

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: of wives: alas, fifteen wives is nothing! eleven

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: widows and nine maids is a simple coming-in for one

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: man: and then to 'scape drowning thrice, and to be

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: in peril of my life with the edge of a feather-bed;

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: here are simple scapes. Well, if Fortune be a

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: woman, she's a good wench for this gear. Father,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: come; I'll take my leave of the Jew in the twinkling of an eye.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Exeunt Launcelot and Old Gobbo

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I pray thee, good Leonardo, think on this:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: These things being bought and orderly bestow'd,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Return in haste, for I do feast to-night

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: My best-esteem'd acquaintance: hie thee, go.

speaker: LEONARDO
text_entry: My best endeavours shall be done herein.

speaker: LEONARDO
text_entry: Enter GRATIANO

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Where is your master?

speaker: LEONARDO
text_entry: Yonder, sir, he walks.

speaker: LEONARDO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Signior Bassanio!

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Gratiano!

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: I have a suit to you.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: You have obtain'd it.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: You must not deny me: I must go with you to Belmont.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Why then you must. But hear thee, Gratiano;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Thou art too wild, too rude and bold of voice;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Parts that become thee happily enough

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And in such eyes as ours appear not faults;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: But where thou art not known, why, there they show

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Something too liberal. Pray thee, take pain

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To allay with some cold drops of modesty

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Thy skipping spirit, lest through thy wild behavior

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I be misconstrued in the place I go to,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And lose my hopes.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Signior Bassanio, hear me:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: If I do not put on a sober habit,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Talk with respect and swear but now and then,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Wear prayer-books in my pocket, look demurely,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Nay more, while grace is saying, hood mine eyes

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Thus with my hat, and sigh and say 'amen,'

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Use all the observance of civility,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Like one well studied in a sad ostent

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: To please his grandam, never trust me more.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Well, we shall see your bearing.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Nay, but I bar to-night: you shall not gauge me

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: By what we do to-night.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: No, that were pity:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I would entreat you rather to put on

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Your boldest suit of mirth, for we have friends

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: That purpose merriment. But fare you well:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I have some business.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: And I must to Lorenzo and the rest:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: But we will visit you at supper-time.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: SCENE III. The same. A room in SHYLOCK'S house.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Enter JESSICA and LAUNCELOT

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: I am sorry thou wilt leave my father so:

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Our house is hell, and thou, a merry devil,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Didst rob it of some taste of tediousness.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: But fare thee well, there is a ducat for thee:

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: And, Launcelot, soon at supper shalt thou see

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Lorenzo, who is thy new master's guest:

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Give him this letter; do it secretly;

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: And so farewell: I would not have my father

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: See me in talk with thee.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Adieu! tears exhibit my tongue. Most beautiful

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: pagan, most sweet Jew! if a Christian did not play

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: the knave and get thee, I am much deceived. But,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: adieu: these foolish drops do something drown my

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: manly spirit: adieu.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Farewell, good Launcelot.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Exit Launcelot

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Alack, what heinous sin is it in me

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: To be ashamed to be my father's child!

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: But though I am a daughter to his blood,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: I am not to his manners. O Lorenzo,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: If thou keep promise, I shall end this strife,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Become a Christian and thy loving wife.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: SCENE IV. The same. A street.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Enter GRATIANO, LORENZO, SALARINO, and SALANIO

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Nay, we will slink away in supper-time,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Disguise us at my lodging and return,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: All in an hour.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: We have not made good preparation.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: We have not spoke us yet of torchbearers.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: 'Tis vile, unless it may be quaintly order'd,

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: And better in my mind not undertook.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: 'Tis now but four o'clock: we have two hours

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: To furnish us.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Enter LAUNCELOT, with a letter

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Friend Launcelot, what's the news?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: An it shall please you to break up

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: this, it shall seem to signify.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I know the hand: in faith, 'tis a fair hand;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And whiter than the paper it writ on

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Is the fair hand that writ.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Love-news, in faith.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: By your leave, sir.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Whither goest thou?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Marry, sir, to bid my old master the

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Jew to sup to-night with my new master the Christian.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Hold here, take this: tell gentle Jessica

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I will not fail her; speak it privately.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Go, gentlemen,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Exit Launcelot

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Will you prepare you for this masque tonight?

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I am provided of a torch-bearer.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Ay, marry, I'll be gone about it straight.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: And so will I.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Meet me and Gratiano

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: At Gratiano's lodging some hour hence.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: 'Tis good we do so.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Exeunt SALARINO and SALANIO

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Was not that letter from fair Jessica?

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I must needs tell thee all. She hath directed

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: How I shall take her from her father's house,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: What gold and jewels she is furnish'd with,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: What page's suit she hath in readiness.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: If e'er the Jew her father come to heaven,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: It will be for his gentle daughter's sake:

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And never dare misfortune cross her foot,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Unless she do it under this excuse,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: That she is issue to a faithless Jew.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Come, go with me; peruse this as thou goest:

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Fair Jessica shall be my torch-beare r.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: SCENE V. The same. Before SHYLOCK'S house.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Enter SHYLOCK and LAUNCELOT

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Well, thou shalt see, thy eyes shall be thy judge,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: The difference of old Shylock and Bassanio:--

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: What, Jessica!--thou shalt not gormandise,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: As thou hast done with me:--What, Jessica!--

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: And sleep and snore, and rend apparel out;--

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Why, Jessica, I say!

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Why, Jessica!

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Who bids thee call? I do not bid thee call.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Your worship was wont to tell me that

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: I could do nothing without bidding.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Enter Jessica

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Call you? what is your will?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I am bid forth to supper, Jessica:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: There are my keys. But wherefore should I go?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I am not bid for love; they flatter me:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: But yet I'll go in hate, to feed upon

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: The prodigal Christian. Jessica, my girl,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Look to my house. I am right loath to go:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: For I did dream of money-bags to-night.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: I beseech you, sir, go: my young master doth expect

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: your reproach.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: So do I his.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: An they have conspired together, I will not say you

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: shall see a masque; but if you do, then it was not

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: for nothing that my nose fell a-bleeding on

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Black-Monday last at six o'clock i' the morning,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: falling out that year on Ash-Wednesday was four

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: year, in the afternoon.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: What, are there masques? Hear you me, Jessica:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Lock up my doors; and when you hear the drum

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: And the vile squealing of the wry-neck'd fife,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Clamber not you up to the casements then,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Nor thrust your head into the public street

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: To gaze on Christian fools with varnish'd faces,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: But stop my house's ears, I mean my casements:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Let not the sound of shallow foppery enter

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: My sober house. By Jacob's staff, I swear,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I have no mind of feasting forth to-night:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: But I will go. Go you before me, sirrah;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Say I will come.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: I will go before, sir. Mistress, look out at

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: window, for all this, There will come a Christian

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: boy, will be worth a Jewess' eye.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: What says that fool of Hagar's offspring, ha?

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: His words were 'Farewell mistress;' nothing else.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: The patch is kind enough, but a huge feeder;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Snail-slow in profit, and he sleeps by day

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: More than the wild-cat: drones hive not with me;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Therefore I part with him, and part with him

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: To one that would have him help to waste

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: His borrow'd purse. Well, Jessica, go in;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Perhaps I will return immediately:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Do as I bid you; shut doors after you:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Fast bind, fast find;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: A proverb never stale in thrifty mind.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Farewell; and if my fortune be not crost,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: I have a father, you a daughter, lost.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: SCENE VI. The same.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Enter GRATIANO and SALARINO, masqued

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: This is the pent-house under which Lorenzo

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Desired us to make stand.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: His hour is almost past.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: And it is marvel he out-dwells his hour,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: For lovers ever run before the clock.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: O, ten times faster Venus' pigeons fly

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: To seal love's bonds new-made, than they are wont

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: To keep obliged faith unforfeited!

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: That ever holds: who riseth from a feast

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: With that keen appetite that he sits down?

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Where is the horse that doth untread again

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: His tedious measures with the unbated fire

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: That he did pace them first? All things that are,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Are with more spirit chased than enjoy'd.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: How like a younker or a prodigal

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: The scarfed bark puts from her native bay,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Hugg'd and embraced by the strumpet wind!

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: How like the prodigal doth she return,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: With over-weather'd ribs and ragged sails,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Lean, rent and beggar'd by the strumpet wind!

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Here comes Lorenzo: more of this hereafter.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Enter LORENZO

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Sweet friends, your patience for my long abode;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Not I, but my affairs, have made you wait:

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: When you shall please to play the thieves for wives,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I'll watch as long for you then. Approach;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Here dwells my father Jew. Ho! who's within?

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Enter JESSICA, above, in boy's clothes

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Who are you? Tell me, for more certainty,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Albeit I'll swear that I do know your tongue.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Lorenzo, and thy love.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Lorenzo, certain, and my love indeed,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: For who love I so much? And now who knows

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: But you, Lorenzo, whether I am yours?

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Here, catch this casket; it is worth the pains.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: I am glad 'tis night, you do not look on me,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: For I am much ashamed of my exchange:

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: But love is blind and lovers cannot see

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: The pretty follies that themselves commit;

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: For if they could, Cupid himself would blush

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: To see me thus transformed to a boy.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Descend, for you must be my torchbearer.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: What, must I hold a candle to my shames?

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: They in themselves, good-sooth, are too too light.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Why, 'tis an office of discovery, love;

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: And I should be obscured.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: So are you, sweet,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Even in the lovely garnish of a boy.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: But come at once;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: For the close night doth play the runaway,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And we are stay'd for at Bassanio's feast.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: I will make fast the doors, and gild myself

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: With some more ducats, and be with you straight.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Exit above

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Now, by my hood, a Gentile and no Jew.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Beshrew me but I love her heartily;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: For she is wise, if I can judge of her,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And true she is, as she hath proved herself,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And therefore, like herself, wise, fair and true,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Shall she be placed in my constant soul.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Enter JESSICA, below

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: What, art thou come? On, gentlemen; away!

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Exit with Jessica and Salarino

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Enter ANTONIO

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Who's there?

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Signior Antonio!

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Fie, fie, Gratiano! where are all the rest?

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: 'Tis nine o'clock: our friends all stay for you.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: No masque to-night: the wind is come about;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Bassanio presently will go aboard:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I have sent twenty out to seek for you.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: I am glad on't: I desire no more delight

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Than to be under sail and gone to-night.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: SCENE VII. Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Flourish of cornets. Enter PORTIA, with the PRINCE OF MOROCCO, and their trains

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Go draw aside the curtains and discover

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: The several caskets to this noble prince.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Now make your choice.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: The first, of gold, who this inscription bears,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire;'

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: The second, silver, which this promise carries,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves;'

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: This third, dull lead, with warning all as blunt,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.'

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: How shall I know if I do choose the right?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: The one of them contains my picture, prince:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If you choose that, then I am yours withal.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Some god direct my judgment! Let me see;

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: I will survey the inscriptions back again.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: What says this leaden casket?

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.'

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Must give: for what? for lead? hazard for lead?

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: This casket threatens. Men that hazard all

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Do it in hope of fair advantages:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: A golden mind stoops not to shows of dross;

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: I'll then nor give nor hazard aught for lead.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: What says the silver with her virgin hue?

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.'

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: As much as he deserves! Pause there, Morocco,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: And weigh thy value with an even hand:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: If thou be'st rated by thy estimation,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Thou dost deserve enough; and yet enough

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: May not extend so far as to the lady:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: And yet to be afeard of my deserving

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Were but a weak disabling of myself.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: As much as I deserve! Why, that's the lady:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: I do in birth deserve her, and in fortunes,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: In graces and in qualities of breeding;

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: But more than these, in love I do deserve.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: What if I stray'd no further, but chose here?

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Let's see once more this saying graved in gold

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.'

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Why, that's the lady; all the world desires her;

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: From the four corners of the earth they come,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: To kiss this shrine, this mortal-breathing saint:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: The Hyrcanian deserts and the vasty wilds

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Of wide Arabia are as thoroughfares now

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: For princes to come view fair Portia:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: The watery kingdom, whose ambitious head

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Spits in the face of heaven, is no bar

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: To stop the foreign spirits, but they come,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: As o'er a brook, to see fair Portia.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: One of these three contains her heavenly picture.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Is't like that lead contains her? 'Twere damnation

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: To think so base a thought: it were too gross

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: To rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Or shall I think in silver she's immured,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Being ten times undervalued to tried gold?

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: O sinful thought! Never so rich a gem

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Was set in worse than gold. They have in England

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: A coin that bears the figure of an angel

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Stamped in gold, but that's insculp'd upon;

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: But here an angel in a golden bed

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Lies all within. Deliver me the key:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Here do I choose, and thrive I as I may!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: There, take it, prince; and if my form lie there,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Then I am yours.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: He unlocks the golden casket

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: O hell! what have we here?

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: A carrion Death, within whose empty eye

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: There is a written scroll! I'll read the writing.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Reads

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: All that glitters is not gold;

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Often have you heard that told:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Many a man his life hath sold

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: But my outside to behold:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Gilded tombs do worms enfold.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Had you been as wise as bold,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Young in limbs, in judgment old,

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Your answer had not been inscroll'd:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Fare you well; your suit is cold.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Cold, indeed; and labour lost:

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Then, farewell, heat, and welcome, frost!

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Portia, adieu. I have too grieved a heart

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: To take a tedious leave: thus losers part.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Exit with his train. Flourish of cornets

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A gentle riddance. Draw the curtains, go.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Let all of his complexion choose me so.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: SCENE VIII. Venice. A street.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Enter SALARINO and SALANIO

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Why, man, I saw Bassanio under sail:

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: With him is Gratiano gone along;

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And in their ship I am sure Lorenzo is not.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: The villain Jew with outcries raised the duke,

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Who went with him to search Bassanio's ship.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: He came too late, the ship was under sail:

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: But there the duke was given to understand

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: That in a gondola were seen together

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Lorenzo and his amorous Jessica:

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Besides, Antonio certified the duke

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: They were not with Bassanio in his ship.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: I never heard a passion so confused,

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: So strange, outrageous, and so variable,

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: As the dog Jew did utter in the streets:

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: 'My daughter! O my ducats! O my daughter!

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Fled with a Christian! O my Christian ducats!

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Justice! the law! my ducats, and my daughter!

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: A sealed bag, two sealed bags of ducats,

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Of double ducats, stolen from me by my daughter!

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: And jewels, two stones, two rich and precious stones,

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Stolen by my daughter! Justice! find the girl;

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: She hath the stones upon her, and the ducats.'

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Why, all the boys in Venice follow him,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Crying, his stones, his daughter, and his ducats.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Let good Antonio look he keep his day,

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Or he shall pay for this.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Marry, well remember'd.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: I reason'd with a Frenchman yesterday,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Who told me, in the narrow seas that part

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: The French and English, there miscarried

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: A vessel of our country richly fraught:

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: I thought upon Antonio when he told me;

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And wish'd in silence that it were not his.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: You were best to tell Antonio what you hear;

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Yet do not suddenly, for it may grieve him.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: A kinder gentleman treads not the earth.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: I saw Bassanio and Antonio part:

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Bassanio told him he would make some speed

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Of his return: he answer'd, 'Do not so;

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Slubber not business for my sake, Bassanio

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: But stay the very riping of the time;

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And for the Jew's bond which he hath of me,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Let it not enter in your mind of love:

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Be merry, and employ your chiefest thoughts

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: To courtship and such fair ostents of love

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: As shall conveniently become you there:'

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And even there, his eye being big with tears,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Turning his face, he put his hand behind him,

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: And with affection wondrous sensible

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: He wrung Bassanio's hand; and so they parted.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: I think he only loves the world for him.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: I pray thee, let us go and find him out

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: And quicken his embraced heaviness

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: With some delight or other.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Do we so.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: SCENE IX. Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Enter NERISSA with a Servitor

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Quick, quick, I pray thee; draw the curtain straight:

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: The Prince of Arragon hath ta'en his oath,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: And comes to his election presently.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Flourish of cornets. Enter the PRINCE OF ARRAGON, PORTIA, and their trains

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Behold, there stand the caskets, noble prince:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If you choose that wherein I am contain'd,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemnized:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But if you fail, without more speech, my lord,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You must be gone from hence immediately.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: I am enjoin'd by oath to observe three things:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: First, never to unfold to any one

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Which casket 'twas I chose; next, if I fail

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Of the right casket, never in my life

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: To woo a maid in way of marriage: Lastly,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: If I do fail in fortune of my choice,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Immediately to leave you and be gone.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To these injunctions every one doth swear

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That comes to hazard for my worthless self.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: And so have I address'd me. Fortune now

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: To my heart's hope! Gold; silver; and base lead.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.'

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: You shall look fairer, ere I give or hazard.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: What says the golden chest? ha! let me see:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.'

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: What many men desire! that 'many' may be meant

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: By the fool multitude, that choose by show,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach;

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Which pries not to the interior, but, like the martlet,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Builds in the weather on the outward wall,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Even in the force and road of casualty.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: I will not choose what many men desire,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Because I will not jump with common spirits

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: And rank me with the barbarous multitudes.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Why, then to thee, thou silver treasure-house;

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Tell me once more what title thou dost bear:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves:'

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: And well said too; for who shall go about

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: To cozen fortune and be honourable

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Without the stamp of merit? Let none presume

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: To wear an undeserved dignity.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: O, that estates, degrees and offices

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Were not derived corruptly, and that clear honour

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Were purchased by the merit of the wearer!

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: How many then should cover that stand bare!

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: How many be commanded that command!

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: How much low peasantry would then be glean'd

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: From the true seed of honour! and how much honour

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Pick'd from the chaff and ruin of the times

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: To be new-varnish'd! Well, but to my choice:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.'

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: I will assume desert. Give me a key for this,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: And instantly unlock my fortunes here.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: He opens the silver casket

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Too long a pause for that which you find there.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: What's here? the portrait of a blinking idiot,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Presenting me a schedule! I will read it.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: How much unlike art thou to Portia!

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: How much unlike my hopes and my deservings!

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves.'

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Did I deserve no more than a fool's head?

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Is that my prize? are my deserts no better?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To offend, and judge, are distinct offices

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And of opposed natures.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: What is here?

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Reads

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: The fire seven times tried this:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Seven times tried that judgment is,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: That did never choose amiss.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Some there be that shadows kiss;

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Such have but a shadow's bliss:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: There be fools alive, I wis,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Silver'd o'er; and so was this.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Take what wife you will to bed,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: I will ever be your head:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: So be gone: you are sped.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Still more fool I shall appear

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: By the time I linger here

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: With one fool's head I came to woo,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: But I go away with two.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Sweet, adieu. I'll keep my oath,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Patiently to bear my wroth.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Exeunt Arragon and train

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Thus hath the candle singed the moth.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: O, these deliberate fools! when they do choose,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: They have the wisdom by their wit to lose.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: The ancient saying is no heresy,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Hanging and wiving goes by destiny.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Come, draw the curtain, Nerissa.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Where is my lady?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Here: what would my lord?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Madam, there is alighted at your gate

speaker: Servant
text_entry: A young Venetian, one that comes before

speaker: Servant
text_entry: To signify the approaching of his lord;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: From whom he bringeth sensible regreets,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: To wit, besides commends and courteous breath,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Gifts of rich value. Yet I have not seen

speaker: Servant
text_entry: So likely an ambassador of love:

speaker: Servant
text_entry: A day in April never came so sweet,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: To show how costly summer was at hand,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: As this fore-spurrer comes before his lord.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: No more, I pray thee: I am half afeard

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Thou wilt say anon he is some kin to thee,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Thou spend'st such high-day wit in praising him.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Come, come, Nerissa; for I long to see

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Quick Cupid's post that comes so mannerly.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Bassanio, lord Love, if thy will it be!

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: SCENE I. Venice. A street.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Enter SALANIO and SALARINO

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Now, what news on the Rialto?

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Why, yet it lives there uncheck'd that Antonio hath

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: a ship of rich lading wrecked on the narrow seas;

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: the Goodwins, I think they call the place; a very

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: dangerous flat and fatal, where the carcasses of many

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: a tall ship lie buried, as they say, if my gossip

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Report be an honest woman of her word.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: I would she were as lying a gossip in that as ever

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: knapped ginger or made her neighbours believe she

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: wept for the death of a third husband. But it is

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: true, without any slips of prolixity or crossing the

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: plain highway of talk, that the good Antonio, the

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: honest Antonio,--O that I had a title good enough

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: to keep his name company!--

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Come, the full stop.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Ha! what sayest thou? Why, the end is, he hath

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: lost a ship.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: I would it might prove the end of his losses.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Let me say 'amen' betimes, lest the devil cross my

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: prayer, for here he comes in the likeness of a Jew.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Enter SHYLOCK

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: How now, Shylock! what news among the merchants?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: You know, none so well, none so well as you, of my

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: daughter's flight.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: That's certain: I, for my part, knew the tailor

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: that made the wings she flew withal.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: And Shylock, for his own part, knew the bird was

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: fledged; and then it is the complexion of them all

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: to leave the dam.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: She is damned for it.

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: That's certain, if the devil may be her judge.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: My own flesh and blood to rebel!

speaker: SALANIO
text_entry: Out upon it, old carrion! rebels it at these years?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I say, my daughter is my flesh and blood.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: There is more difference between thy flesh and hers

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: than between jet and ivory; more between your bloods

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: than there is between red wine and rhenish. But

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: tell us, do you hear whether Antonio have had any

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: loss at sea or no?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: There I have another bad match: a bankrupt, a

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: prodigal, who dare scarce show his head on the

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Rialto; a beggar, that was used to come so smug upon

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: the mart; let him look to his bond: he was wont to

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: call me usurer; let him look to his bond: he was

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: wont to lend money for a Christian courtesy; let him

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: look to his bond.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Why, I am sure, if he forfeit, thou wilt not take

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: his flesh: what's that good for?

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: To bait fish withal: if it will feed nothing else,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: it will feed my revenge. He hath disgraced me, and

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: hindered me half a million; laughed at my losses,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: mocked at my gains, scorned my nation, thwarted my

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: bargains, cooled my friends, heated mine

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: enemies; and what's his reason? I am a Jew. Hath

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: not a Jew eyes? hath not a Jew hands, organs,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: dimensions, senses, affections, passions? fed with

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: to the same diseases, healed by the same means,

speaker: SHYLOCK

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: That ever blotted paper! Gentle lady,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: When I did first impart my love to you,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I freely told you, all the wealth I had

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Ran in my veins, I was a gentleman;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And then I told you true: and yet, dear lady,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Rating myself at nothing, you shall see

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: How much I was a braggart. When I told you

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: My state was nothing, I should then have told you

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: That I was worse than nothing; for, indeed,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I have engaged myself to a dear friend,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Engaged my friend to his mere enemy,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To feed my means. Here is a letter, lady;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The paper as the body of my friend,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And every word in it a gaping wound,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Issuing life-blood. But is it true, Salerio?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Have all his ventures fail'd? What, not one hit?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: From Tripolis, from Mexico and England,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: From Lisbon, Barbary and India?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And not one vessel 'scape the dreadful touch

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Of merchant-marring rocks?

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Not one, my lord.

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Besides, it should appear, that if he had

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: The present money to discharge the Jew,

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: He would not take it. Never did I know

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: A creature, that did bear the shape of man,

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: So keen and greedy to confound a man:

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: He plies the duke at morning and at night,

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: And doth impeach the freedom of the state,

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: If they deny him justice: twenty merchants,

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: The duke himself, and the magnificoes

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Of greatest port, have all persuaded with him;

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: But none can drive him from the envious plea

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Of forfeiture, of justice and his bond.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: When I was with him I have heard him swear

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: To Tubal and to Chus, his countrymen,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: That he would rather have Antonio's flesh

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Than twenty times the value of the sum

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: That he did owe him: and I know, my lord,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: If law, authority and power deny not,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: It will go hard with poor Antonio.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The dearest friend to me, the kindest man,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The best-condition'd and unwearied spirit

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: In doing courtesies, and one in whom

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The ancient Roman honour more appears

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Than any that draws breath in Italy.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: What sum owes he the Jew?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: For me three thousand ducats.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: What, no more?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Pay him six thousand, and deface the bond;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Double six thousand, and then treble that,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Before a friend of this description

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Shall lose a hair through Bassanio's fault.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: First go with me to church and call me wife,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And then away to Venice to your friend;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: For never shall you lie by Portia's side

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: With an unquiet soul. You shall have gold

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To pay the petty debt twenty times over:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: When it is paid, bring your true friend along.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: My maid Nerissa and myself meantime

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Will live as maids and widows. Come, away!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: For you shall hence upon your wedding-day:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Bid your friends welcome, show a merry cheer:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Since you are dear bought, I will love you dear.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But let me hear the letter of your friend.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: [Reads]  Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: miscarried, my creditors grow cruel, my estate is

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: very low, my bond to the Jew is forfeit; and since

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: in paying it, it is impossible I should live, all

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: debts are cleared between you and I, if I might but

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: see you at my death. Notwithstanding, use your

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: pleasure: if your love do not persuade you to come,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: let not my letter.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: O love, dispatch all business, and be gone!

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Since I have your good leave to go away,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I will make haste: but, till I come again,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: No bed shall e'er be guilty of my stay,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: No rest be interposer 'twixt us twain.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: SCENE III. Venice. A street.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Enter SHYLOCK, SALARINO, ANTONIO, and Gaoler

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Gaoler, look to him: tell not me of mercy;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: This is the fool that lent out money gratis:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Gaoler, look to him.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Hear me yet, good Shylock.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I'll have my bond; speak not against my bond:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I have sworn an oath that I will have my bond.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Thou call'dst me dog before thou hadst a cause;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: But, since I am a dog, beware my fangs:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: The duke shall grant me justice. I do wonder,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Thou naughty gaoler, that thou art so fond

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: To come abroad with him at his request.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I pray thee, hear me speak.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I'll have my bond; I will not hear thee speak:

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I'll have my bond; and therefore speak no more.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I'll not be made a soft and dull-eyed fool,

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: To shake the head, relent, and sigh, and yield

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: To Christian intercessors. Follow not;

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: I'll have no speaking: I will have my bond.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: It is the most impenetrable cur

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: That ever kept with men.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Let him alone:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I'll follow him no more with bootless prayers.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: He seeks my life; his reason well I know:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I oft deliver'd from his forfeitures

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Many that have at times made moan to me;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Therefore he hates me.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: I am sure the duke

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Will never grant this forfeiture to hold.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: The duke cannot deny the course of law:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: For the commodity that strangers have

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: With us in Venice, if it be denied,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Will much impeach the justice of his state;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Since that the trade and profit of the city

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Consisteth of all nations. Therefore, go:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: These griefs and losses have so bated me,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: That I shall hardly spare a pound of flesh

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To-morrow to my bloody creditor.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Well, gaoler, on. Pray God, Bassanio come

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To see me pay his debt, and then I care not!

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: SCENE IV. Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Enter PORTIA, NERISSA, LORENZO, JESSICA, and BALTHASAR

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Madam, although I speak it in your presence,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: You have a noble and a true conceit

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Of godlike amity; which appears most strongly

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: In bearing thus the absence of your lord.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: But if you  knew to whom you show this honour,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: How true a gentleman you send relief,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: How dear a lover of my lord your husband,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I know you would be prouder of the work

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Than customary bounty can enforce you.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I never did repent for doing good,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Nor shall not now: for in companions

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That do converse and waste the time together,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Whose souls do bear an equal yoke Of love,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: There must be needs a like proportion

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Of lineaments, of manners and of spirit;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which makes me think that this Antonio,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Being the bosom lover of my lord,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Must needs be like my lord. If it be so,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: How little is the cost I have bestow'd

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: In purchasing the semblance of my soul

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: From out the state of hellish misery!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: This comes too near the praising of myself;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Therefore no more of it: hear other things.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Lorenzo, I commit into your hands

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: The husbandry and manage of my house

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Until my lord's return: for mine own part,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I have toward heaven breathed a secret vow

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To live in prayer and contemplation,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Only attended by Nerissa here,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Until her husband and my lord's return:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: There is a monastery two miles off;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And there will we abide. I do desire you

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Not to deny this imposition;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: The which my love and some necessity

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Now lays upon you.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Madam, with all my heart;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I shall obey you in all fair commands.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: My people do already know my mind,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And will acknowledge you and Jessica

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And so farewell, till we shall meet again.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Fair thoughts and happy hours attend on you!

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: I wish your ladyship all heart's content.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I thank you for your wish, and am well pleased

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To wish it back on you: fare you well Jessica.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Exeunt JESSICA and LORENZO

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Now, Balthasar,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: As I have ever found thee honest-true,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: So let me find thee still. Take this same letter,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And use thou all the endeavour of a man

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: In speed to Padua: see thou render this

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Into my cousin's hand, Doctor Bellario;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And, look, what notes and garments he doth give thee,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Bring them, I pray thee, with imagined speed

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Unto the tranect, to the common ferry

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which trades to Venice. Waste no time in words,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But get thee gone: I shall be there before thee.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Madam, I go with all convenient speed.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Come on, Nerissa; I have work in hand

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That you yet know not of: we'll see our husbands

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Before they think of us.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Shall they see us?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: They shall, Nerissa; but in such a habit,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That they shall think we are accomplished

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: With that we lack. I'll hold thee any wager,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: When we are both accoutred like young men,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I'll prove the prettier fellow of the two,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And wear my dagger with the braver grace,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And speak between the change of man and boy

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: With a reed voice, and turn two mincing steps

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Into a manly stride, and speak of frays

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Like a fine bragging youth, and tell quaint lies,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: How honourable ladies sought my love,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which I denying, they fell sick and died;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I could not do withal; then I'll repent,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And wish for all that, that I had not killed them;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And twenty of these puny lies I'll tell,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That men shall swear I have discontinued school

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Above a twelvemonth. I have within my mind

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A thousand raw tricks of these bragging Jacks,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which I will practise.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Why, shall we turn to men?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Fie, what a question's that,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If thou wert near a lewd interpreter!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But come, I'll tell thee all my whole device

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: When I am in my coach, which stays for us

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: At the park gate; and therefore haste away,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: For we must measure twenty miles to-day.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: SCENE V. The same. A garden.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Enter LAUNCELOT and JESSICA

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Yes, truly; for, look you, the sins of the father

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: are to be laid upon the children: therefore, I

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: promise ye, I fear you. I was always plain with

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: you, and so now I speak my agitation of the matter:

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: therefore be of good cheer, for truly I think you

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: are damned. There is but one hope in it that can do

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: you any good; and that is but a kind of bastard

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: hope neither.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: And what hope is that, I pray thee?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Marry, you may partly hope that your father got you

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: not, that you are not the Jew's daughter.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: That were a kind of bastard hope, indeed: so the

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: sins of my mother should be visited upon me.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Truly then I fear you are damned both by father and

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: mother: thus when I shun Scylla, your father, I

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: fall into Charybdis, your mother: well, you are

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: gone both ways.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: I shall be saved by my husband; he hath made me a

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Christian.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Truly, the more to blame he: we were Christians

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: enow before; e'en as many as could well live, one by

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: another. This making Christians will raise the

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: price of hogs: if we grow all to be pork-eaters, we

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: shall not shortly have a rasher on the coals for money.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Enter LORENZO

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: I'll tell my husband, Launcelot, what you say: here he comes.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I shall grow jealous of you shortly, Launcelot, if

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: you thus get my wife into corners.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Nay, you need not fear us, Lorenzo: Launcelot and I

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: are out. He tells me flatly, there is no mercy for

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: me in heaven, because I am a Jew's daughter: and he

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: says, you are no good member of the commonwealth,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: for in converting Jews to Christians, you raise the

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: price of pork.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I shall answer that better to the commonwealth than

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: you can the getting up of the negro's belly: the

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Moor is with child by you, Launcelot.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: It is much that the Moor should be more than reason:

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: but if she be less than an honest woman, she is

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: indeed more than I took her for.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: How every fool can play upon the word! I think the

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: best grace of wit will shortly turn into silence,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: and discourse grow commendable in none only but

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: parrots. Go in, sirrah; bid them prepare for dinner.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: That is done, sir; they have all stomachs.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Goodly Lord, what a wit-snapper are you! then bid

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: them prepare dinner.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: That is done too, sir; only 'cover' is the word.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Will you cover then, sir?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Not so, sir, neither; I know my duty.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Yet more quarrelling with occasion! Wilt thou show

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: the whole wealth of thy wit in an instant? I pray

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: tree, understand a plain man in his plain meaning:

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: go to thy fellows; bid them cover the table, serve

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: in the meat, and we will come in to dinner.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: For the table, sir, it shall be served in; for the

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: meat, sir, it shall be covered; for your coming in

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: to dinner, sir, why, let it be as humours and

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: conceits shall govern.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: O dear discretion, how his words are suited!

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: The fool hath planted in his memory

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: An army of good words; and I do know

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: A many fools, that stand in better place,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Garnish'd like him, that for a tricksy word

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Defy the matter. How cheerest thou, Jessica?

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And now, good sweet, say thy opinion,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: How dost thou like the Lord Bassanio's wife?

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Past all expressing. It is very meet

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: The Lord Bassanio live an upright life;

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: For, having such a blessing in his lady,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: He finds the joys of heaven here on earth;

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: And if on earth he do not mean it, then

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: In reason he should never come to heaven

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Why, if two gods should play some heavenly match

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: And on the wager lay two earthly women,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: And Portia one, there must be something else

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Pawn'd with the other, for the poor rude world

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Hath not her fellow.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Even such a husband

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Hast thou of me as she is for a wife.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Nay, but ask my opinion too of that.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I will anon: first, let us go to dinner.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Nay, let me praise you while I have a stomach.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: No, pray thee, let it serve for table-talk;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: ' Then, howso'er thou speak'st, 'mong other things

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I shall digest it.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Well, I'll set you forth.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: SCENE I. Venice. A court of justice.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Enter the DUKE, the Magnificoes, ANTONIO, BASSANIO, GRATIANO, SALERIO, and others

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: What, is Antonio here?

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Ready, so please your grace.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I am sorry for thee: thou art come to answer

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: A stony adversary, an inhuman wretch

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: uncapable of pity, void and empty

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: From any dram of mercy.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I have heard

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Your grace hath ta'en great pains to qualify

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: His rigorous course; but since he stands obdurate

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And that no lawful means can carry me

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Out of his envy's reach, I do oppose

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: My patience to his fury, and am arm'd

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To suffer, with a quietness of spirit,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: The very tyranny and rage of his.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Go one, and call the Jew into the court.

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: He is ready at the door: he comes, my lord.

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Enter SHYLOCK

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Make room, and let him stand before our face.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Shylock, the world thinks, and I think so too,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That thou but lead'st this fashion of thy malice

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: To the last hour of act; and then 'tis thought

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Thou'lt show thy mercy and remorse more strange

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Than is thy strange apparent cruelty;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And where thou now exact'st the penalty,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Which is a pound of this poor merchant's flesh,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Thou wilt not only loose the forfeiture,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But, touch'd with human gentleness and love,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Forgive a moiety of the principal;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Glancing an eye of pity on his losses,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That have of late so huddled on his back,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Enow to press a royal merchant down

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And pluck commiseration of his state

speaker: PORTIA
